associations.sentence: DPYD*1 mentioned in article but not studied by paper.
associations.explanation: No association or genotype-specific outcomes for DPYD*1 are described in the provided text.
citations: The group of patients with partial DPD deficiency represented a total of 580 patients, including 134 wild-type patients (DPYD1/1) and 446 patients harboring at least one genetic variant (208 patients carried one genetic variant and 238 patients more than one).

The remaining 2392 patients exhibiting normal DPD activity include 623 wild-type patients (DPYD1/1) and 1769 mutated patients in which a total of 3183 genetic variants were identified (831 carrying a single genetic variant and 938 carrying more than one).
However, information regarding fluoropyrimidine toxicity was not available.

associations.sentence: Genotypes TG + GG of DPYD*13 (rs55886062) are associated with decreased DPD activity (predicting increased risk of fluoropyrimidine toxicity) with fluoropyrimidines in people eligible for an uracil analog-based chemotherapy as compared to genotype TT.
associations.explanation: In this large French cohort (~3,000 patients), the study confirms the strong impact of this clinically rare variant on DPD enzyme activity using pretreatment uracil and UH2/U phenotyping; significance was reported but exact p-values were not provided in the text.
citations: Dose adjustment based on pretreatment screening for the most clinically relevant DPYD defective variants, i.e. c.1679T>G (DPYD13, rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (DPYD2A, rs3918290) and c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val or rs67376798), has been shown to improve the safety of chemotherapy regimens based on fluorouracil [[29](#CR29)].
As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).
n = number of patients; ***P < 0.001; ****P < 0.0001.
Specifically, our results confirmed the strong impact of the three clinically rare variants.

associations.sentence: Genotypes GA + AA of rs3918290 are associated with decreased DPD activity (predicting increased risk of fluoropyrimidine toxicity) with fluoropyrimidines in people eligible for an uracil analog-based chemotherapy as compared to genotype GG.
associations.explanation: The study reports a strong effect of this rare splice-site variant on DPD function in a cohort of about 3,000 French patients, based on pretreatment uracil and UH2/U ratio phenotyping; detailed p-values are not provided in the excerpt.
citations: Dose adjustment based on pretreatment screening for the most clinically relevant DPYD defective variants, i.e. c.1679T>G (DPYD13, rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (DPYD2A, rs3918290) and c.2846A>T (p.Asp949Val or rs67376798), has been shown to improve the safety of chemotherapy regimens based on fluorouracil [[29](#CR29)].
As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).
n = number of patients; ***P < 0.001; ****P < 0.0001.
Specifically, our results confirmed the strong impact of the three clinically rare variants.

associations.sentence: Genotypes CG + GG of rs56038477 (HapB3 tag) are associated with modestly decreased DPD activity with fluoropyrimidines in people eligible for an uracil analog-based chemotherapy as compared to genotype CC.
associations.explanation: The study notes a significant but modest association between common variants including HapB3 and DPD activity in this large French cohort; exact effect sizes and p-values are not provided in the excerpt.
citations: The association between common DPYD genetic variants (MAF ≥ 1%) and DPD activity is summarized in Fig. [2](#Fig2).

Among the seven genetic variants identified, three variants (c.1236G>A or rs56038477 p.Glu412Glu ; c.496A>G or rs2297595 p.Met166Val; DPYD6 c.2194G>A or rs1801160 p.Val732Ile) were significantly more frequent in the group of patients exhibiting partial DPD deficiency.
Consistent with previous reports, the c.1236G>A (rs56038477) which is included in the risk haplotype B3 was significantly associated with low DPD activity [[30](#CR30), [31](#CR31)].
n = number of patients, ns = non-significant; *P < 0.05, **P < 0.01.

associations.explanation: The paper confirms the strong impact of this clinically rare variant on DPD function using pretreatment uracil-based phenotyping in ~3,000 patients; detailed statistics are not included in the provided text.

As expected, our data showed a significant association between each of these genetic variants and low DPD activity (Fig. [1](#Fig1)).

n = number of patients; ***P < 0.001; ****P < 0.0001.
Specifically, our results confirmed the strong impact of the three clinically rare variants.

result.summary:
## Background
Fluoropyrimidines (5‑fluorouracil/capecitabine) rely on dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD; gene DPYD) for clearance. Reduced DPD activity increases drug exposure and risk of severe toxicity. In ~3,000 patients, the authors sequenced DPYD exons and splice junctions and measured pretreatment DPD activity using the plasma dihydrouracil/uracil (UH2/U) ratio to assess how common and rare variants relate to DPD deficiency.

## Key Findings
- Established high‑risk variants strongly associated with reduced DPD activity:
  - c.1679T>G (DPYD*13; rs55886062), c.1905+1G>A (DPYD*2A; rs3918290), and c.2846A>T (rs67376798) were each linked to significantly lower UH2/U ratios (P < 0.001–0.0001), consistent with higher toxicity risk at standard dosing.
- Several common variants showed modest associations with lower DPD activity:
  - hapB3 tag c.1236G>A (rs56038477), c.496A>G (p.Met166Val; rs2297595), and DPYD*6 c.2194G>A (p.Val732Ile; rs1801160) were more frequent in partially deficient patients (P < 0.05–0.01), but effects were smaller than the established high‑risk variants.
- Rare variants substantially contribute to low DPD activity:
  - Variants with MAF <1% were enriched in patients with low DPD activity (9.3% vs 3.2%; P < 1×10^-5).
  - This enrichment persisted after excluding the three established high‑risk variants (4.5% vs 2.6%; P < 0.03).
  - Predicted deleterious rare variants (MAF <1%, CADD >15), excluding the three high‑risk variants, were also enriched (4.2% vs 1.6%; P < 0.001).
  - Rare loss‑of‑function findings included frameshift DPYD*7 c.299_302del (rs539032572), splice‑site c.2766+1G>A, nonsense p.Trp650*, start‑loss c.1A>G, and other missense/splice variants detected largely in heterozygosity.

Note: Clinical toxicity outcomes were not captured; associations are with DPD phenotype (UH2/U ratio), a validated surrogate of toxicity risk.

## Clinical Implications
- Preemptive DPYD testing should not be limited to the standard trio (DPYD*2A, *13, c.2846A>T) and hapB3. Comprehensive next‑generation sequencing that captures rare, potentially deleterious variants can improve identification of patients with reduced DPD activity and at risk for fluoropyrimidine toxicity.
- Use genotype‑guided dosing per current guidelines for known high‑risk alleles; consider dose reduction or alternative therapy when rare predicted loss‑of‑function variants are found, ideally corroborated by DPD phenotyping.
- Combining comprehensive DPYD genotyping with phenotyping (when available) offers the most robust strategy to minimize fluoropyrimidine toxicity without compromising efficacy.
